title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #1058: Are there only finitely many n in [p_{k-1}, p_k) such that n!+1 is divisible only by p_k and p_{k+1}? SOLVED by Luca (2001): The only solutions are n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

title: Prime Sequence
content: The prime sequence p₁ = 2, p₂ = 3, p₃ = 5, p₄ = 7, ... enumerates all primes in increasing order. The problem relates n's position in this sequence to divisibility of n!+1.

title: Interval Condition
content: n ∈ [p_{k-1}, p_k) means p_{k-1} ≤ n < p_k. For example, n=4 is in [3,5) since p₂=3 and p₃=5. The interval determines which primes p_k and p_{k+1} are relevant.

title: Divisibility Condition
content: The only primes dividing n!+1 must be p_k and p_{k+1}. This is extremely restrictive - n!+1 typically has many prime factors, so finding cases with only two is rare.

title: Erdős-Stewart Conjecture
content: Erdős and Stewart conjectured that only finitely many n satisfy the condition. This appears as Problem A2 in Guy's 'Unsolved Problems in Number Theory'.

title: Luca's Theorem
content: Luca (2001): The only n satisfying the Erdős-Stewart condition are n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. This completely classifies all solutions - there are exactly five.

title: Case n = 1
content: 1! + 1 = 2 = 2¹. The only prime factor is 2 = p₁. This satisfies the condition since n=1 is in the appropriate interval and 2 is the relevant prime.

title: Case n = 4
content: 4! + 1 = 25 = 5². The only prime factor is 5 = p₃. Since n=4 is in [p₂, p₃) = [3, 5), and 5 = p₃, this satisfies the condition.

title: Case n = 5
content: 5! + 1 = 121 = 11². The only prime factor is 11 = p₅. Since n=5 is in [p₃, p₄) = [5, 7), this satisfies the condition with p₄=7 and p₅=11.

title: Case n = 6 Fails
content: 6! + 1 = 721 = 7 × 103. Since 103 is prime and 103 > p₅ = 11, this has 'extra' prime factors beyond p_k and p_{k+1}. The condition fails for n = 6.

title: Wilson's Theorem
content: Wilson's theorem: (p-1)! ≡ -1 (mod p) for prime p. This means p divides (p-1)!+1. If n = p_k - 1, then p_k divides n!+1, which explains why certain primes appear.

title: Factorial Growth
content: n! grows extremely fast (faster than exponential). For large n, n!+1 has many prime factors simply because it's so large. This makes the restricted factorization condition increasingly rare.

title: Lower Bound Technique
content: For n ≥ 6, n!+1 grows faster than any power of p_{k+1}. If n!+1 = p_k^a · p_{k+1}^b, the size forces a third prime factor to exist.

title: Diophantine Methods
content: Luca's proof combines growth rate arguments with diophantine equation techniques. By analyzing the equation n!+1 = p_k^a · p_{k+1}^b, all cases with n ≥ 6 are eliminated.

title: Related: n!+1 = m²
content: The equation n!+1 = m² has known solutions n = 4, 5, 7 (giving 25 = 5², 121 = 11², 5041 = 71²). This is related to Brocard's problem, which asks if there are infinitely many.

title: Brocard's Problem
content: Brocard's problem: Are there infinitely many n with n!+1 = m²? This famous open problem is related but different - it asks for perfect squares, not restricted prime factorizations.

title: Luca's Contributions
content: Florian Luca is a renowned specialist in diophantine equations involving factorials and special sequences. He has solved many Erdős problems in this area using sophisticated techniques.

title: Final Status
content: erdos_1058_status: The Erdős-Stewart conjecture is PROVED. There are only finitely many solutions (exactly 5), namely n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Complete classification achieved by Luca (2001).
